title: DOM Introduction
subject: JavaScript
theory:
When a web page is loaded, the browser creates a **D**ocument **O**bject **M**odel of the page.
The DOM is a tree-like representation of the HTML.

JavaScript gets all the power it needs to create dynamic HTML through the DOM.

*   `document.getElementById(id)`
*   `document.querySelector(css_selector)`
syntax:
const title = document.getElementById('main-title');
const items = document.querySelectorAll('.list-item');

common_mistakes.correction: If script runs before HTML loads, DOM elements won't exist yet. Put script at bottom or use `defer`.
common_mistakes.example: Result: 'null' when trying to select element.

interview_questions.question: Difference between `querySelector` and `getElementById`?
interview_questions.answer: getElementById is faster and specific to ID. querySelector is versatile (uses CSS syntax like #id, .class) but slightly slower.

practice_problems.problem: Select the first paragraph on the page.

real_world_use_cases.description: Virtual DOM is used by frameworks to mimic DOM but faster.

exam_notes: querySelectorAll returns a NodeList (not exactly an Array).
DOM is an API, not JS itself.
summary: The DOM is the bridge between JavaScript and visible HTML.
